titleStmt.title: Letter from William F. Cody to George T. Beck, October 27, 1895
titleStmt.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
titleStmt.sponsor: Supported in part by a grant from the Wyoming Cultural Trust Fund, a program of the Department of State Parks and Cultural Resources.

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

notesStmt.note: Includes envelope transcription without image. BBWW performed in Atlanta, Georgia, October 28 - November 2, 1895. William E. Hymer (~1853-1933) was one of the early members of the Shoshone Land and Irrigation Company.

bibl.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
bibl.title: Letter from William F. Cody to George T. Beck

msIdentifier.repository: University of Wyoming, American Heritage Center, Buffalo Bill Letters to George T. Beck (Acc. #9972)

div1.note:
The Buffalo Bill Wild West and Congress of Rough Riders of the World. Col. W. F. Cody (Buffalo Bill), President.
Nate Salsbury, Vice-Pres't and Manager.
John M. Burke, . . . General Manager.
Albert E. Scheible, . . . Business Manager.
Jule Keen, . . . Treasurer.
div1.p: Did Hymer pay the our engineers for the work they done in surveying the Town Site. If he did we haventhaven't a leg to stand on. And I would not have lost that Town site for $25000 in cash. Oh why did you not do as I asked you to. that was to take up that land. Hymer now claims it all I would like to know what you propose to do— is he going to beat you at every turn in the game? So far he has got the lead— I am watching waiting to see if you give up the game— or are you going to be as cute as he is— I would do some thing. But there is no other location like the one he has surveyed Why did you give him our Surveyors to survey a Town Site3 for him self. When we wanted the Town for our selves? I hope you can fix it up. I hate to loose that site— try and let me know soon—

div1.note: The Buffalo Bill Wild West and Congress of Rough Riders of the World.

back.note: Note 1: Buffalo Bill's Wild West performed in Atlanta, Georgia, from October 28 - November 2, 1895, during the run of The Cotton States and International Exposition, also known as the Atlanta Exposition.
Note 2: The year is not inscribed by Cody but is 1895 as determined by the Routes List.
